question: Which of the following are DDL statements in SQL?  Select one or more as applicable.
Which of the following are DML statements in SQL? Select one or more as applicable.
Which of the following data type specifications would be suitable for a column to store the numeric data 221.78 as is (without rounding off)?  Select one or more as applicable.
Which of the following operations in SQL will result in irrecoverable loss of data? Select one or more as applicable.
Which of the following statements is / are TRUE?  Select one or more as applicable.

options.option1: A CHAR (10) field will store ‘John’ in 4 bytes saving the remaining 6 bytes

options.option2: A CHAR(10) field will store ‘John’ as 10 bytes appending 6 trailing spaces

options.option3: A VARCHAR2(10) field will store ‘John’ as 10 bytes appending 6 trailing spaces

options.option4: A VARCHAR2(10) field will store ‘John’ as 6 bytes (assuming 2 bytes to store length) saving the rest

question: Which of the following statements are true in SQL?  Select one or more as applicable.

options.option1: Primary Key constraint cannot be defined at column level

options.option2: NOT NULL constraint can be defined only at column level

options.option3: DEFAULT clause can be given only for fields with NOT NULL constraint

options.option4: UNIQUE constraint allows multiple records to have NULL entry

question: Which of the following requirements can be implemented with a CHECK constraint?  Select one or more as applicable.

options.option1: Every Student must have a name

options.option2: Age of Students must be greater than 18

options.option3: Two Students cannot have the same roll number

options.option4: Students must be from Karnataka  State

options.option5: Every Student must be assigned to any of the available disciplines

question: Which of the following statements is / are true about Foreign Keys in RDBMS?  Select one or more.

options.option1: A foreign key field in a relation can refer to a primary key field in the same or a different relation

options.option2: A foreign key field in a relation  can refer to any field with UNIQUE constraint in the same or different relation

options.option3: A foreign key field in a relation must always refer to a primary key field in the same or a different relation

options.option4: A foreign key field in a relation  can refer to any field with NOT NULL constraint in the same or different relation

options.option5: A foreign key field in a relation  cannot refer to another field in the same relation

question: Predict the output of the following SQL Statement.  Assume that Student table is not pre-existing.

options.option2: Composite Primary Key will be created with Name as first attribute

options.option3: Composite Primary Key will be created with DoB as first attribute

options.option4: Two separate primary keys will be created

question: Consider the following table: Student(RollNo, Name, EmailAddress, Age) where a combination of two columns (RollNo, EmailAddress) together should be unique.  Which of the following is correct in this context?

options.option1: Apply UNIQUE constraint separately for both columns

options.option2: Put Primary Key constraint on both columns separately

options.option3: Apply a table level UNIQUE constraint involving both the columns

options.option4: It is impossible to give such a constraint

question: Consider a Product table has been created already as given below.  Assume that there are no records in the table. There is a new requirement that category column must have some value.  Which of the following statements can be used for implementing this?

options.option1: ALTER TABLE Product ADD CONSTRAINT prod_cat_nn NOT NULL (category);

options.option2: ALTER TABLE Product MODIFY category CONSTRAINT prod_cat_nn NOT NULL;

options.option3: ALTER TABLE Product MODIFY CONSTRAINT prod_cat_nn NOT NULL (category);

options.option4: ALTER TABLE Product  ADD CONSTRAINT prod_cat_nn NOT NULL (category);

question: Consider the following Student table which is already created. Which of the following INSERT statements will execute successfully?
Consider the following Student table which is already created. Which of the following INSERT statements will execute successfully?

options.option1: INSERT INTO Student(RollNo, DateofBirth) VALUES( 1, NULL);

options.option2: INSERT INTO Student(RollNo, Name, Gender, DateofBirth) VALUES(1000, 'Annie', 'F', NULL);
